curriculumAlignment.outcomeDescription: Energy appears in different forms, including movement (kinetic energy), heat and potential energy, and energy transformations and transfers cause change within systems
keyIndicators: Describe energy transformations in common devices
Apply the law of conservation of energy
Explain efficiency and energy loss as heat

keyConcepts.name: Energy forms
keyConcepts.description: Different types of energy: kinetic, potential (gravitational, elastic, chemical), thermal, light, sound, electrical

keyConcepts.name: Kinetic energy
keyConcepts.description: Energy of motion, dependent on mass and velocity squared (KE = 1/2 mv^2)

keyConcepts.name: Gravitational potential energy
keyConcepts.description: Stored energy due to height above ground (GPE = mgh)

keyConcepts.name: Other potential energies
keyConcepts.description: Elastic potential (stretched/compressed objects) and chemical potential (stored in bonds)

keyConcepts.name: Energy transformations
keyConcepts.description: Energy changes from one form to another but is never created or destroyed

keyConcepts.name: Conservation of energy
keyConcepts.description: Total energy in a closed system remains constant; energy is transferred, not lost

keyConcepts.name: Energy efficiency
keyConcepts.description: Ratio of useful energy output to total energy input; some energy always becomes thermal

keyConcepts.name: Energy degradation
keyConcepts.description: Energy spreads out and becomes less useful over time; explains why perpetual motion is impossible

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Objects at rest have no energy
commonMisconceptions.correction: Stationary objects can have potential energy (gravitational, elastic, chemical) even without moving
Kinetic energy depends on velocity squared, so doubling speed quadruples kinetic energy (KE = 1/2 mv^2)

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Energy is used up or consumed
commonMisconceptions.correction: Energy is never used up; it transforms into other forms, often spreading as thermal energy
Potential energy includes elastic (springs, rubber bands) and chemical (food, fuels, batteries)

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Energy and force are the same thing
commonMisconceptions.correction: Force is a push or pull; energy is the capacity to do work. Force can transfer energy but they are different concepts

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Heat and temperature are the same
commonMisconceptions.correction: Heat is thermal energy being transferred; temperature measures average particle kinetic energy

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Heavier objects fall faster so have more kinetic energy at impact
commonMisconceptions.correction: All objects fall at the same rate (ignoring air resistance), but heavier objects do have more KE because KE depends on mass

commonMisconceptions.misconception: 100% efficiency is achievable with better technology
commonMisconceptions.correction: Some energy always spreads as thermal energy due to friction, air resistance; perfect efficiency violates thermodynamics

realWorldPhenomena.curiosityHook: Why don't roller coasters need an engine after the first hill?
realWorldPhenomena.explanation: GPE at top converts to KE going down; each subsequent hill must be shorter due to energy lost to friction

realWorldPhenomena.curiosityHook: Why does a bouncing ball eventually stop?
realWorldPhenomena.explanation: Each bounce converts some kinetic energy to thermal and sound energy, reducing the height it can reach

realWorldPhenomena.curiosityHook: Why does your phone get warm when playing games?
realWorldPhenomena.explanation: Chemical energy in battery transforms to electrical, then some becomes unwanted thermal energy (inefficiency)

realWorldPhenomena.phenomenon: Food gives you energy to exercise
realWorldPhenomena.curiosityHook: How does a sandwich help you run a race?
realWorldPhenomena.explanation: Chemical potential energy in food transforms to kinetic energy of muscle movement plus thermal energy

realWorldPhenomena.curiosityHook: How can a trampoline make you jump higher than you started?
realWorldPhenomena.explanation: Your kinetic energy stores as elastic PE in the trampoline, then returns as kinetic energy

realWorldPhenomena.curiosityHook: How does falling water light up a city?
realWorldPhenomena.explanation: Water's GPE converts to KE as it falls, then to electrical energy through turbines and generators

realWorldPhenomena.curiosityHook: Where does a car's motion go when it brakes?
realWorldPhenomena.explanation: Kinetic energy transforms to thermal energy through friction in brake pads; energy isn't destroyed

realWorldPhenomena.curiosityHook: Why is a fast bowler's delivery so much more dangerous than a slow one?
realWorldPhenomena.explanation: Doubling speed quadruples kinetic energy; fast bowlers transfer much more energy on impact
Light energy transforms to electrical energy; efficiency is typically 15-22% with the rest becoming heat

realWorldPhenomena.curiosityHook: How do electric cars get extra range when going downhill?
realWorldPhenomena.explanation: Instead of wasting KE as heat in brakes, regenerative braking converts it back to chemical PE in the battery

scaffoldingSequence: Energy forms identification → Kinetic energy concept → Potential energy types → Energy transformations → Conservation principle → Efficiency calculations → Energy degradation understanding

kineticEnergy.keyInsight: Velocity is squared, so doubling speed quadruples energy

variables.g: gravitational field strength (9.8 m/s² on Earth)

gravitationalPotentialEnergy.keyInsight: Height is measured from a reference point; the choice of zero is arbitrary

efficiency.formula: Efficiency = (useful energy output / total energy input) × 100%

variables.useful output: energy that does the intended job
variables.total input: all energy put into the system

efficiency.keyInsight: Efficiency is always less than 100% due to friction and other losses

cognitiveLoadNotes: Introduce energy forms with familiar examples before abstract definitions
Use visual diagrams showing energy flow and transformations
Separate kinetic energy formula understanding from calculations initially
Present conservation law after students see multiple transformation examples
engagementStrategies: Start with sports examples (cricket, football) to hook student interest
Use prediction activities: 'Which ball will go higher?' before explaining
Create cognitive dissonance with bouncing ball losing height vs conservation
Connect to sustainability and climate change for relevance
motivationFactors: Relate to video games and phone battery life
Connect to sports performance and athletic training
Link to renewable energy and environmental responsibility
Show how understanding energy helps in everyday decisions
commonStumblingPoints: Velocity squared in KE formula is counterintuitive
Applying conservation when energy seems to 'run out'
desirableDifficulties: Mix energy forms questions to prevent pattern matching
Include near-transfer problems (familiar context, new values)
Include far-transfer problems (new contexts, same principles)

formativeIdeas: Energy flow diagrams for everyday devices
Sorting activities: Which objects have which types of energy?
Error analysis: Find the mistake in this energy calculation
summativeExpectations: Calculate KE and GPE for given scenarios
Trace energy transformations through multi-step processes
Explain why perpetual motion is impossible
Calculate efficiency and identify energy losses
